Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Versatile Biobased Plastics from Omega-hydroxylated fatty acids
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will create a family of bioplastics containing omega-hydroxyfatty acid (omega-HOFAs) repeat units to fill a gap in commercially available bioplastics. First, the effects of omega-HOFA chain length on corresponding polymer (P[omega-HOFA]) material properties will be elucidated. Then, reactive blending methods will be studied to generate bioplastics that exploit both polylactic acid (PLA) strength and P(omega-HOFA) ductility. Blend process parameters (e.g. time, temperature, catalyst, and catalyst concentration) will be varied to adjust P(omega-HOFA)/PLA transesterification which will result in ?fine-tuning? of phase compatibility and optimization of blend physical-mechanical properties. We anticipate that, relative to PLA, P(omega-HOFA)/PLA blends will have significantly improved hydrolytic stability, impact resistance, and warp resistance. Requirements will be established for reactor configuration and corresponding process variables as a function scale for both P(omega-HOFA) synthesis and reactive blending. Furthermore, the compostability of P(omega-HOFAs) and P(omega-HOFAs)/PLA will be determined. Successful completion of the proposed Phase I research program will result in a thorough analysis of material thermal and physico-mechanical properties needed for identification of commercial applications and to further engage strategic industrial partners.

The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to develop new biobased materials that meet evolving needs of consumers while providing cost-performance advantages over existing products. Many current bioplastics have inherent problems that limit their market penetration. Of particular relevance to this program is PLA that is hindered in its potential use due to its brittle behavior, inadequate vapor transmission properties, hydrolytic instability, and low impact strength. Our omega-HOFAs provide a versatile readily renewable building block to the plastics industry that through homopolymerization, copolymerization and blending can be used to produce a wide-range of bioplastics with desired physical and mechanical properties. Preliminary work on blends of P(omega-HOFAs) with PLA show that many deficiencies of PLA, such as its brittle behavior, are eliminated while blends show important improvements in strength relative to P(omega-HOFAs). This work will focus on gaining fundamental information on the physical-mechanical properties of these blend materials as the degree of transesterification is manipulated by reactive blending. Furthermore, an understanding will be gained on how blending effects the biodegradability of both components. The outcome of this work will be renewable biodegradable plastics that out-perform their petroleum derived competitors and decrease our dependency on petroleum for chemical production.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This report for the Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project describes work performed by SyntheZyme to develop a bio-based polyester from fatty acids in natural plant oils. The bio-based polyester feels, behaves and can be melt-processed (e.g. forming films, molded part and fibers) just like polyethylene. However, unlike polyethylene, SyntheZyme bio-based polyesters have many additional uses and they rapidly biodegrade in compost environments. Furthermore, SyntheZyme’s bio-based plastics fill a critical gap in current commercially available materials. They are made from w-hydroxyfatty acids (w-HOFA) building blocks strung together to make large bio-based polyester molecules called poly(w-hydroxyfatty acids), P(w-HOFAs). To make large quantities of w-HOFA monomers, SyntheZyme uses its engineered yeast to add a reactive group (hydroxyl moiety) at one end of plant oil-derived fatty acids. During the Phase I program, we demonstrated that our yeast strain can produce monomer from low cost plant oil fatty acids. Furthermore, we showed that the resulting biobased polyester had highly desirable properties. However, conversions to produce monomer are slower than is needed to develop a low cost monomer production method. Therefore, during the Phase II program, work will be conducted to improve the yeast strains efficiency for monomer production.

      The only biobased polyester that’s commercially available in large quantities is poly(lactic acid), PLA. Unforturnately, PLA has deficiencies such as being stiff or brittle so that it easily breaks when stretched. SyntheZyme discovered that when it when it mixed by reactive blending small amounts (as little as 5%) of P(w-HOFAs) with PLA, the resulting P(w-HOFAs)/PLA blends were no longer brittle. Instead, they could be stretched about two times their original length. The key to this discovery was developing a method where the two components react sufficiently with each other during processing that they are compatible or interact closely.  Blends of P(w-HOFAs) with PLA vary in strength and ductility (ease of being stretched) as a function of the blend composition. Hence, material properties of blends can be ‘tuned’ by simply changing the blend ratio of P(w-HOFAs)-to-PLA. This development has important commercial potential as it improves an existing product by using small amounts of our newly developed P(w-HOFAs). The Phase II program will further advance this work by improving the blending process and scaling this operation so that it can be used on commercial scale processing equipment.   

      Compostability testing was performed to determine P(w-HOC14) film biodegradability in a laboratory simulated compost test according to a standard testing method (ISO14855). Results of this test show SyntheZyme P(w-HOC14) is readily compostable in simulated composting conditions such that conversion of polymer carbon to CO2 reached 95% in about 55 days.

      Finally, the ease of transferring the fermentation process for w-HOC14 production to another facility at larger scale was assessed. Without process optimization, fermentations were performed in a 40 L fermentor at Renssalear Polytechnic Institutes Biotechnology Center. Similar product yields (~120 g/L) of w-HOC14 were obtained by 80 h fermentations at 5 and 40 L scales indicating that the scale-up was successful. The Phase II program describes an exciting collaboration with Meredian that will develop larger-scale fermentation processes using our newly developed monomer production yeast strain. 


Last Modified: 07/30/2012
Modified by: Jiali Cai

The bio-based polyester feels, behaves and can be melt-processed (e.g. forming films, molded part and fibers) just like polyethylene. However, unlike polyethylene, SyntheZyme bio-based polyesters have many additional uses and they rapidly biodegrade in compost environments. Furthermore, SyntheZymeÆs bio-based plastics fill a critical gap in current commercially available materials. They are made from w-hydroxyfatty acids (w-HOFA) building blocks strung together to make large bio-based polyester molecules called poly(w-hydroxyfatty acids), P(w-HOFAs). To make large quantities of w-HOFA monomers, SyntheZyme uses its engineered yeast to add a reactive group (hydroxyl moiety) at one end of plant oil-derived fatty acids. During the Phase I program, we demonstrated that our yeast strain can produce monomer from low cost plant oil fatty acids. Furthermore, we showed that the resulting biobased polyester had highly desirable properties. However, conversions to produce monomer are slower than is needed to develop a low cost monomer production method. Therefore, during the Phase II program, work will be conducted to improve the yeast strains efficiency for monomer production. The only biobased polyester thatÆs commercially available in large quantities is poly(lactic acid), PLA. Unforturnately, PLA has deficiencies such as being stiff or brittle so that it easily breaks when stretched. SyntheZyme discovered that when it when it mixed by reactive blending small amounts (as little as 5%) of P(w-HOFAs) with PLA, the resulting P(w-HOFAs)/PLA blends were no longer brittle. Instead, they could be stretched about two times their original length. The key to this discovery was developing a method where the two components react sufficiently with each other during processing that they are compatible or interact closely. Blends of P(w-HOFAs) with PLA vary in strength and ductility (ease of being stretched) as a function of the blend composition. Hence, material properties of blends can be ætunedÆ by simply changing the blend ratio of P(w-HOFAs)-to-PLA. This development has important commercial potential as it improves an existing product by using small amounts of our newly developed P(w-HOFAs). The Phase II program will further advance this work by improving the blending process and scaling this operation so that it can be used on commercial scale processing equipment. Compostability testing was performed to determine P(w-HOC14) film biodegradability in a laboratory simulated compost test according to a standard testing method (ISO14855). Results of this test show SyntheZyme P(w-HOC14) is readily compostable in simulated composting conditions such that conversion of polymer carbon to CO2 reached 95% in about 55 days. The Phase II program describes an exciting collaboration with Meredian that will develop larger-scale fermentation processes using our newly developed monomer production yeast strain.
